newsitem.title: FRANCE: Cerus to repay debt with Valeo proceeds.
newsitem.headline: Cerus to repay debt with Valeo proceeds.

text.p: French holding company Cerus said on Tuesday it will use an expected 6.7 billion francs from the sale of its 28 percent stake in car parts maker Valeo to pay down bank debt and redeem bonds.

"Cerus will use the proceeds of these operations to repay its debt and retain cash necessary for its own needs tied to the management of its current portfolio," Cerus chairman Michel Cicurel told a news conference.
Proceeds of the Valeo stake sale would not go to Carlo De Benedetti's Olivetti, he said. De Benedetti controls the Cerus group.
Cerus will immediately repay 1.3 billion francs of bank debt and in March 1997, redeem 0.3 billion francs of warrant bonds, he said.

The holding company will also prepay eight million convertible bonds issued at 128 francs. Bondholders who want to take cash, will get 129.74 francs per bond plus interest as stated in the issue contract.

Those opting to convert for shares have until March 2 to decide. The conversion terms are likely to be around nominal value of 100 francs per share, although the exact amount will depend on the numbers being converted and the 1996 results.
After the debt repayment, Cerus will have around three billion francs of non-strategic assets to sell, he said.

"Cerus will have around three billion francs of assets, none of which is strategic, even Cofir," he said. Cerus will sell the assets and invest the proceeds in industrial and service companies in France and Europe, with the exception of the banking sector.

The assets consist of 48.1 percent in the Spanish Cofir holding company, valued at 700 million francs, 500 million francs of residential properties in central Paris near Monceau Park, 900 million of assets from its Dumenil-Leble investment bank and 650 million in deposits which have been frozen as part of a legal dispute involving Dumenil.

Cicurel reaffirmed a forecast estimate that Valeo would be worth 400 francs per share in 1998. "We are currently in the process of selling Valeo...at 20 times the earnings estimated by analysts. I believe that in 1997 Valeo will make 1.45 billion francs in profit. Twenty times the 1997 earnings per share makes 400 francs, he said.
Valeo made 1995 profit of one billion francs on turnover of 25.2 billion.
